title: Thursday, 19th January, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

Morning

PM11:01am

I should warn you straight up that I'm a tad tired and irritated

PM11:02am

Hopefully Bryce is in a better mood

11:01 am
PM11:02am

Than me at least

PM11:02am

Had to spend too long dealing with tech issues

PM11:02am

And given too much attention to reading drivel

11:02 am
PM11:02am

Look at this for example

PM11:02am

It's titled "The End of Traffic"

PM11:03am

On Medium

11:02 am
PM11:03am

Smart Lanes With A Universal Free Option
The idea of ending traffic might sound too good to be true, but it’s as simple as three key steps.

PM11:03am

Bet you can't wait

PM11:03am

...

11:03 am
BE11:03am

......... They mean traffic as in cars?

PM11:03am

Yeah

PM11:03am

Based on local traffic data across the country, city, and regional governments should classify specific streets and highways as smart lanes.
Next, a federal infrastructure fund should be created to provide grants to those cities and states that establish eligible smart lane infrastructure sufficient to eliminate traffic.
Last, the recipients should re-invest all funds generated by these smart lanes back into hard infrastructure like roads and bridges, creating jobs, as well as into public transit, using the smart lanes to give buses faster travel times and further increase accessibility.

11:03 am
BE11:03am

Not traffic as in internet whatever? Okay.

PM11:04am

Those are the three revolutionary steps

PM11:04am

You'll be wanting to know the names of the geniuses behind this

11:04 am
PM11:04am

John Zimmer and Logan Green, Lyft Co-Founders

PM11:04am

https://medium.com...c03207d#.pczo6btll

PM11:05am

Increasing American Prosperity and Quality of Life

11:05 am
PM11:05am

I'm minded to pen a piece called The End of Guff

BE11:05am

Well yes, this is all very nice.

BE11:05am

Meanwhile ......... the temporary traffic lights outside the Royal Oak malfunctioned and were permanently set at red this morning, locking about a third of NW10 in gridlock as a guy in a high-vis jacket stared impassively at the control box.

11:06 am
BE11:06am

Making me half an hour late for work. That's the reality of it. Guff doesn't factor in temporary traffic light timings and guys in high-vis jackets.

PM11:06am

True

PM11:07am

Let's try and move to markets. It's safer

11:06 am
undefined
PM11:07am

US/China relations big talking point overnight

PM11:07am

It's Obama's last day in office!

11:07 am
PM11:07am

End of Hope

PM11:08am

Ive mentioned before that a good source on China is ..

PM11:08am

Sinocism

11:07 am
PM11:08am

I'd say it's a must now

BE11:08am

(@Patience: who called you alarmist? Not us, I hazard.)

PM11:08am

Get on their mailing list https://sinocism.c...&mc_eid=76995729c5

11:08 am
PM11:08am

I wish I could tell you what the incoming Trump administration intends for China but so far there is a lot of noise and uncertainty, including around who will actually be driving and implementing policies that affect the relationship. It certainly looks like we should expect a much tougher line, something that could be constructive as long as there is a strategy, proper sequencing, and some sobriety behind all the bluster. So far those things are not apparent.

One move that would be a sign of just how much animosity the Trump folks feel towards China would be announcing things sure to upset Beijing on the evening of January 27, or on January 28, Chinese New Year’s Eve and Chinese New Year’s Day.

Meanwhile back in Beijing we see continued ideological tightening with more emphasis on ideological conformity and obedience as well further moves to crackdown on “historical nihilism”, especially when it comes to Chairman Mao. 2017 is shaping up to be a very tense year inside the PRC, and expect it to only get worse if tensions with the US increase.

PM11:08am

That's Bill at Sinocism

undefined
11:09 am
PM11:09am

Obama deserves a quick pic of the day

PM11:09am

PM11:09am

Yep. Bye.

11:09 am
undefined
PM11:10am

So Bryce, bull markets over

PM11:10am

Footsie off 44 points

11:10 am
PM11:10am

Better to travel towards Trump land than actually arrive

BE11:11am

Yup, one can pin it on politics (on which we've had a fair bit of warning, really) though it's more logical to say pound up FTSE down.

PM11:11am

You always say that Bryce

11:11 am
PM11:11am

Or vice versa

BE11:11am

I do, because it's all that's happening from a top-down perspective.

PM11:12am

Top down markets are not good for bottom up stock market reporters

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Automatic ban to any of the rabble pick up on the phrase "bottom up stock market reporters" , just as a warning. Okay, so where to we start on the micro level?

BE11:13am

It's busy, trading statement wise.

PM11:13am

This is true

11:13 am
BE11:13am

There's also a bit of M&A, though not UK.

BE11:14am

Safran buying Zodiac, finally.

PM11:14am

Ah yes, I saw your explosive reaction overnight (on our private Slack channel)

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Well, not explosive. Just a bit fatigued with the game of shadowboxing that M&A reporting has become.

PM11:15am

This is yet another deal where the company concerned was asked about a deal that didn't exist, decided it might actually be a good idea, but failed to pay any commission for the advice

BE11:15am

Possibly. We don't know for sure.

11:15 am
PM11:15am

You don't know how to monetise yourself Bryce

BE11:15am

My guess on what happened is that Safran-Zodiac were in talks last year. Detailed, quite advanced talks.

BE11:16am

I can go down the advisor and lawyer list if I must, but won't. Anyway, we put that story to various people last year and were told it was entirely wrong.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Then, a month or two later, Bloomberg picked up the same story (which I'd guess was by this time stale or at least dormant, having gone pens down at the first leak).

BE11:17am

And again we were told it was entirely wrong.

BE11:17am

Now, as of today .... Well who'd have thought!

11:18 am
BE11:18am

I guess we can get the finders' fee for putting the idea in Safran's heads.

BE11:18am

It's a better earnings model than journalism these days, quite frankly.

BE11:18am

Let me chuck up some grey to detail what stage we're at.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Sandy Morris at Jefferies, who we quote a lot on here because he's good.

BE11:19am

Given Safran’s focus on the “more electrical aircraft” and last October’s acquisition of B/E Aerospace by Rockwell Collins, Safran’s €9.7bn offer for Zodiac is no great surprise. The €5.50 per share special dividend and promise of double-digit EPS accretion in 2019 arguably sweeten matters too. What we cannot decide upon is whether the share-based consideration strengthens Safran’s long-term investment case.

BE11:20am

By way of comparison. On 23 October 2016, Rockwell Collins announced the acquisition of B/E Aerospace for a total consideration of around US$8.3bn. B/E’s equity was valued at US $6.4bn, with 55% of the consideration satisfied in cash. The revenues of B/E Aerospace for the 12 months ended September 2016 were US$2.86bn, the implied transaction multiple
being 2.9 times. Rockwell projected cost synergies of around US$160m at a one-time cost of US$120m, plus purchase accounting benefits of US$60-90m per annum for six years. The
advantage to Rockwell was that the combination diversified its portfolio, with Air Transport rising from around 30% of Group sales to over 50% on a pro-forma basis. The acquisition
also roughly doubled Rockwell’s exposure to the Civil Aftermarket – to around 25% of pro-forma Group revenues. Finally, the acquisition brought Rockwell’s sales to the International and USA markets broadly into balance. Nonetheless, the Rockwell share price fell from US $84.46 on 21 October (Friday) to US$79.21 on 24 October 2016. It now stands at US$89.60

11:20 am
BE11:20am

(Skipping a bit)

BE11:20am

Take a pew. At this time, we can only seek to set a context for the transaction. On a stand-alone financial basis, the acquisition of Zodiac appears pretty attractive, in our view. We venture the planned special dividend may also lend near-term support to the Safran share price. We believe the one obvious drawback is that Safran’s shareholding structure ends up somewhat more complicated, albeit there will be a two-year lock-up agreement encompassing the Zodiac family shareholders and major Zodiac investors. Looking at things in a broader context, we have long considered Safran to be a highly ambitious company that sought greater scale and that it was willing to broaden the scope of its activities to achieve that. In this case, the planned divestments of Morpho Detection and the Security division arguably mean that Safran becomes more focused on Aerospace. What may be open to debate is whether Zodiac enhances the investment case. We recognise much of Zodiac’s business can be said to be Aftermarket, but we do not believe it to be of the same quality as the Propulsion Aftermarket or the services revenues generated by braking systems and landing gear. Still, it is probably better to take a pew rather than rush to a conclusion.

BE11:21am

And Goldman ......

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Our previous conversations with investors have consistently suggested that there was little support for this transaction, owing to (1) ongoing execution issues at Zodiac; and (2) the ongoing challenge of the LEAP ramp up. We would therefore expect this announcement to be taken negatively. However, as part of the deal, there is a €5.5 special dividend for Safran shareholders, equal to 8% of the current market cap, which could suppress any downside move. Furthermore, the synergy target (€200 mn) is a positive while the deal is expected to be double-digit accretive to EPS within the first full year. Finally, Philippe Petitcolin will remain as Safran CEO and the CEO maximum age is extended from 65 to 68, in effect potentially extending his term to 2021.

BE11:22am

So that's where we are, and that's where that one is.

undefined
11:22 am
PM11:22am

thanks for all that

BE11:22am

Oh, just before we move on from M&A .......

BE11:22am

.... Streetinsider doing its "according to a person claiming to have knowledge of the matter" thing overnight.

11:22 am
BE11:23am

http://www.streeti...urce/12435628.html

BE11:23am

Swiss packaged food giant Nestle is interested in acquiring Mead Johnson (NYSE: MJN), an Illinois-based company that manufactures and sells infant formulas or other nutritional products, according to a person claiming to have knowledge of the matter.

PM11:23am

Difficult to weigh that one

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Well, you say that. But all the conversations we've had overnight suggests it's rubbish.

BE11:23am

Complete bobbins.

PM11:24am

Is it fair then to say that Streetinsider haven't had a good run?

11:24 am
BE11:25am

They did the BATS stalling story, which seems to have been wildly exaggerated at best.

BE11:25am

And Mead Johnson has a long history of attracting hot money.

BE11:26am

And the current fog in the M&A channel makes all this stuff especially tricky. Nevertheless, let's just say: don't bet your house on it being true.

11:25 am
undefined
PM11:26am

Shall we go to some of these trading statement

PM11:26am

Awful trading statements -- some of them

11:26 am
PM11:26am

Some

PM11:27am

http://www.investe...1701190700115549U/

PM11:27am

St Ives for one

11:27 am
PM11:27am

Grocery flyers not flying

PM11:27am

It's Marketing Activation division

PM11:27am

supermarket offers, mainly i think

11:27 am
PM11:27am

It's not quite clear why that is suddenly such a mess for St Ives

PM11:28am

But the price reaction has been brutal

PM11:28am

results will be a "material" miss

11:28 am
PM11:28am

Material = greater than 20 per cent in City-speak

PM11:28am

But the stock...

ST Ives PLC (SIV:LSE): Last: 78.25, down 48.25 (-38.14%), High: 90.00, Low: 74.75, Volume: 3.67m
11:28 am
BE11:29am

Hm. Looks a mess. Here's Numis.

BE11:29am

St. Ives has released a disappointing trading update for the H1 to January 2017 and we lower our PBT/EPS estimates by -22% to £25m/13.7p for FY17. Strategic Marketing revenues are expected to rise +9% for H1 on a reported basis, and be broadly flat underlying, as although new work to replace deferrals/cancellations has been secured, this is taking longer than expected to come through. Marketing Activation revenues are expected to fall -2%, though margin has been impacted by increased competition. Books had a good half (revenues +13%) bolstered by the JK Rowling titles. We lower our PBT/EPS estimates to £25.0m/13.7p (was £32.4m/17.8p) for FY17 with the shortfall due to margin pressure in Marketing Activation (-£5m) and timing issues in Strategic Marketing (-£2m). From a lower base, we arrive at £27.0m/14.8p (£34.0m/18.7p) for 2018E. Net debt/EBITDA is NSe 2.0x for FY17 and we maintain our forecast for a twice-covered, held dividend of 7.8p which provides a 6% yield. Our target price falls to 155p (was 190p) and though we expect the shares to fall this morning we view the value of St Ives as underpinned by the SM division which, in our view, is experiencing timing issues.

BE11:29am

Strategic Marketing. H1 revenues are expected to rise +9% on a reported basis, bolstered by the TAB acquisition and FX. On an underlying basis, revenues are broadly flat as new work that has been won to replace deferrals/cancellations has taken longer than expected to come through. We lower our FY17 profit estimate by £2m, which we view as being due to timing issues.
Marketing Activation. H1 revenues are expected to fall -2%, a marked improvement on the -7% decline experienced in FY16. However, while new clients have been secured to diversify the cost base, this has been at lower margins. The group has taken cost action to mitigate margin pressure, but this will not come through until fiscal Q4 and we lower our FY17 profit estimate by £5m.
Books. The division had a good H1, with sales +13% bolstered by the JK Rowling titles.
Balance sheet. We forecast Net Debt/EBITDA will finish fiscal 2017 at 2.0x, compared with a covenant of 2.5x. We then expect leverage to fall to 1.8x in 2018.
Forecasts. We lower our PBT/EPS estimates to £25.0m/13.7m (was £32.4m/17.8p) for FY17. From a lower base, we arrive at £27.0m/14.8p (£34.0m/18.7p) for 2018E.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

And Singer.

BE11:29am

Marketing activation has been impacted by further decline in grocery retail impacting profit by c£5m. Strategic The Company is also taking this opportunity to revise its guidance fro Strategic Marketing as its recovery pace is not running at the planned target rate. PBT falls from N1Se £31.9m to £25m. The Company expects dividend to be held based upon lowered guidance and the implied cash flow performance. There do not appear to be any covenant issues. Forecasts and TP under review and downgrade to Hold. We expect the shares to test the 100p level.

BE11:29am

Don't really have anything more detailed.

11:29 am
PM11:30am

We''l yes, then tested 100p and failed

PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets Live

undefined
11:30 am
PM11:30am

City job losses mentioned no the right

PM11:31am

We should quickly share this Handelsblatt story

PM11:31am

But yes, German press on the City of London...

11:31 am
PM11:31am

Saying Goldman is going to halve it's workforce here

PM11:31am

Let me get the translation...

PM11:32am

The Proposed referendum on United Kingdom membership of the European Union strategy of the British government forces the relocation plans of the banks: Goldman Sachs will halve probably the jobs in London, strengthen Frankfurt and set up a European bank there. HSBC 's Paris preference.

First published 19.01.2017 07:50:42

When Theresa May the heads of US banks as Jamie Dimon of this Thursday JP Morgan and Lloyd Blankfein of Goldman Sachs applies, you are facing a difficult task. At this event, on the edge of the Davos World Economic Summit, the British Prime Minister has to try to persuade the top bankers to keep their business in London as intact as possible and to refrain from large-scale relocations.

The bank chiefs should leave May's plea unimpressed. Since the Brexit referendum at the end of June, they are working on emergency plans, which are now pushing them forward - for now it is clear that the UK wants to leave the European internal market. The Prime Minister said this more clearly than before. For the financial sector, one of the most important employers and taxpayers in the country, it is clear that this is not going to happen.

Goldman Sachs has therefore already begun to implement its planned relocation. These are expected to cause the US investment bank to halve its workforce in London to about 3,000 and reorganize its Frankfurt business as the Handelsblatt learned from financial circles. According to Main, a European company formed a 'Europe SE' - as the Swiss UBS has already registered late last year in the commercial register.

11:32 am
PM11:32am

Make your own mind up on that.

PM11:32am

Goldman just saying no decision have been made

PM11:33am

1000 Goldmanites moving to Frankfurt? That'll be fun for them

11:33 am
undefined
BE11:33am

Oh, and since yo mention job losses, Bloomberg picked up on the Panmure P45 rumour we ran a few days ago.

BE11:34am

Exits include Paul Modlock, head of sales, it reports.

11:34 am
PM11:34am

hmm

BE11:34am

Hugh Rich, Nick Cutting, Harinder Sandhu .... All very senior people.

BE11:35am

The suggestion we had earlier in the week -- which I stress is entirely speculative -- was that the exits could suggest Panmure might be preparing itself for the long-rumoured merger.

11:35 am
BE11:36am

With a similarly sized peer, as in Arden or whoever. I stress, total speculation.

BE11:36am

Though Panmure has its annual press lunch this afternoon, so it might be a topic that comes up.

PM11:36am

But educated speculation, perhaps

11:36 am
BE11:36am

Perhaps.

undefined
PM11:37am

Royal Mail now mentioned on the right

11:36 am
PM11:37am

It is top of the Footsie fallers list

PM11:37am

Quite often finds itself on that side of the screen

PM11:37am

What's the problem now?

11:37 am
BE11:37am

UK market remains tough. Fewer letters. Wage inflation.

PM11:38am

http://www.investe...1701190700105494U/

BE11:38am

It's a continuation of previous trends rather than anything new.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

RBC summarises as well as anyone.

BE11:39am

RMG Christmas trading (Q3) saw a further softening of letter volumes but a good trend on Parcels unit revenues continue (after +1% in H1) with 9mo-2016/17 overall addressed letter volume down 6% YoY (~-5% H1 working day adjusted, RMG goal -4% to -6% pa) so addressed letter mail volume decline increased to ~-7% (worse than plan) while advertising mail remained weaker (like in H1). RMG claim the PY Q3 comparative included the effect of the return of direct delivery mail, but this would suggest this then masked a higher decline rate in the PY Q3.

Parcel volumes up 2% vs. 2.9% in H1 or +2% H1 working day adjusted. BDO data suggest in some weeks online retail sales grew at up to 20% pa – suggesting RMG continued to focus on price/quality not just market share. Parcel revenue/consignment was up 1% for 9mo-16/17 so after H1 we think this implies price/mix continued to be held into peak demand pre-Christmas (though it did not improve).

Pensions, wages, costs: UKPIL still faces the need to reach agreement on pension (DB to DC) changes this quarter, plus the present wage deal (+1.6%) expires at the end of this quarter too. The focus on net avoided cost remains but wages/labour cost represent 67% of UKPIL costs so purges on pensions and wage rates are crucial next hurdles for the shares. We think any deal will also need to open the way to move to an increased proportion of a more fully rounded sequence sorted mail delivery bag in future (in line with developments elsewhere in Europe) to further improve productivity.

GLS demand solid – currency translation benefit continues: The mostly European GLS operation did well and 9mo-15/16 saw revenues (in Euro) grow 9% on volumes up 8% (organic) after H1 delivered ~10% underlying volume growth working day adjusted, so Q3 grew ~6% underlying though RMG had previously stated it expected H1 growth was unusual and expected it to normalize.

Our View: As a consequence, this suggests to us that with UK PIL revenues (-2%) declining faster than costs (with cost avoidance plan unchanged), margin is likely to be lower YoY. With the super adjusted EBIT range at £687m-£730m (RBCe £696m) initial impression back of envelope estimates suggest it might tighten down to the lower quartile (1% less letter mail volume would reduce a top end £730m to ~£690m for example).

On RBCe RMG shares trade at 5.3% DPS yield (vs. 5.3% in January, 2016) vs. European peers at 5.4% (who we think have overall less imminent risk factors and where the differential with sovereign bond yield is about 1%pt higher. Recent reduction in planned RMG capex means DPS yield is now better covered – so effective, while RMGs 13.9x YA PER compares to European peers at ~13.8x Key way-points for the share price are:

Continued improvement of price/mix in Parcels – as RMG gains further pricing traction (which has a greater incremental margin that pure volume-led growth) reflecting its unique position in the delivery market (breadth and scope of network). Any price/mix growth about 1% pa would be accretive to the RBCe RMG LN outlook.
Direction of UK letter mail volumes (addressed and unaddressed as the UK GDP growth rate decelerates – normally a driver of increase volume attrition rates). Each 1% change in letter mail volumes vs RBCe (-4.3% 2016/17E, -6.2% 2017/18E on a 1% adverse working day effect) sees a ~£40m revenue and EBIT impact and an 11% EPS swing effect. The share’s EPS is highly operationally geared to small outlook changes.
Presently unknown direction of Pension and wage settlements in UKPIL, and impact on potential property value absorbed by stakeholders, not equity.

BE11:39am

(I say "summarises"..... that might be longer than the RNS.)

11:39 am
BE11:39am

And Jefferies, more briefly.

BE11:39am

Inflection point approaching. The triennial valuation of the Royal Mail defined benefit scheme is still in progress, but Royal Mail confirmed the scheme will have to be closed since the costs of accrual have ballooned to £1.4bn p.a. compared to current cash contributions of c.£400m p.a., with the balance funded by the £1.6bn actuarial pension surplus, which is expected to be exhausted during 2018. As a result, 90,000 employees will move to a relatively less attractive DC scheme, which we assume will be partly mitigated by relatively higher wage inflation of 2.5% p.a. going forward and a one-off incentive payment compensating for the estimated hidden value in the London development property of around £500m.

Valuation / Risk Factors. Royal Mail shares are trading at 7.5x adjusted FY17E EBIT, in-line with the sector, but only if pension cash contributions can be maintained at the current level. Note that the shares are trading at 11.2x IFRS FY17E EBIT, implying a 35% premium to the sector. The shares offer a 5.2% dividend yield, but the dividend is only 1.5x covered by free cash flow, based on current pension cash contributions of £400m per annum. Our 390p DCF-based price target implies 13% downside potential and assumes a one-off incentive payment related to the pension reform compensates for the hidden value in London development property of £500m (50p per share). Key risk factors include increasing e-substitution in a weaker UK economy, increasing competition from DHL in B2C parcels, upcoming labour and pension reform discussions and competition fines.

undefined
11:40 am
BE11:40am

We can just rattle through the rest of the updates.

BE11:40am

Pets, for instance.

Pets at Home Group PLC (PETS:LSE): Last: 217.43, down 20.67 (-8.68%), High: 230.40, Low: 213.10, Volume: 1.97m
11:40 am
PM11:40am

http://www.investe...1701190700105463U/

BE11:40am

Retail weak.

BE11:41am

LFL just 0.1%, against a consensus forecast of +1.3%.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Third straight quarter of slowing growth.

BE11:41am

And its weakest since IPO three years ago.

BE11:42am

Which once again raises all sorts of questions about the Pets model.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

As in, how much does expansion cannibalise existing sales?

BE11:42am

How much does it rely on the Vets side to drive business to the retail side?

BE11:43am

And if you'll excuse me for a moment, the vets side is fascinating

11:43 am
PM11:43am

is it?

BE11:44am

Vets with any kind of ambition absolutely need to grow, because if they don't they'll have no customers within a decade. Pets just don't live that long.

BE11:44am

They can never close their doors to new customers.

11:44 am
BE11:45am

Which has created this weird structure of small single operators and chains that Pets At Home and the other Aim-listed one is trying to disrupt.

PM11:45am

I thought vets were a well established racket -- feeding on the trend for pandered pooches

PM11:45am

We stopped taking our cats to the vet cos it was such an obvious shakedown

11:46 am
PM11:46am

All the stupid jabs on an annualised basis

PM11:46am

They're just cats

BE11:46am

Yes, there's that. But what's important for PETS is that the economies of scale really aren't that great for a vet.

11:46 am
PM11:46am

ok

BE11:47am

You need to provide an after-hours service, for instance, which is only really only scalable in urban areas.

BE11:47am

And there's a clear passthrough between the retail side and the vets side.

11:47 am
BE11:48am

There's an argument that PETS hit the point of diminishing returns in terms of its expansion then floated.

PM11:48am

For now tho, they are trying to impose pretty cheeky margins. Costs more to get a cat's fur trimmed than it does to get a 20 somthing daughter hair done in central london

PM11:48am

Something very wrong there

11:48 am
BE11:48am

(@Pi1010: yes, that's an excellent point.)

BE11:48am

Anyway. Here's Morgan Stanley.

BE11:49am

- Despite the company operating from 4.5% more stores than last year, total merchandise revenues in the quarter were only flat. Although there was one less trading day in the quarter and the figure is only marginally worse than consensus was expecting (+2.7%), we do think this is indicative of growing structural pressures faced by Pets at Home (which has a merchandise gross margin of more than 55% but is increasingly competing against discounters and online specialists whose business models require gross margins of only c30%).

11:49 am
BE11:49am

Service revenues, however, continue to grow very strongly - up 47.8% (vs a consensus expectation of +49.8%) - driven in part by an big increase in the number of vet practices (up 16% YoY) and the acquisition during 2016 of a number of specialist veterinary hospitals

BE11:49am

- We have yet to speak to the company this morning, but the statement makes clear that the company remains comfortable with current market expectations. According to Bloomberg consensus is currently expecting the company to deliver Pre Tax Profits for FY 2016/17e of £97m (giving EPS of 15.3p),
- Based on existing consensus forecasts, Pets at Home is trading on 15.3x Cal 2017 earnings, 9.8x EBITDA, with a 3.3% dividend yield. This compares with a UK General Retail sector trading on 12.8x, 7.7x and 3.8% respectively.

undefined
11:50 am
BE11:50am

Oh, while I have Morgan Stanley research open ......

PM11:50am

go on

Card Factory PLC (CARD:LSE): Last: 236.76, down 11.94 (-4.80%), High: 248.40, Low: 236.76, Volume: 395.52k
11:51 am
BE11:51am

This is Geoff Ruddell again, cutting forecasts.

BE11:51am

Card Factory may be about to report a negative LfL for FY
2016/17 – the first in its 20-year history. Although we do not
see the greetings card market moving heavily online, we fear it
may be becoming a victim of 'collateral damage'.

BE11:51am

We don't see footfall trends improving, so we now model zero LfL growth at Card Factory for the foreseeable future, which leads us to lower our long-term forecasts and our price target significantly. However, with the company still very cash generative and continuing to enjoy competitive advantages, we do not see sufficient further downside on a 12-18 month view to turn sellers, and remain Equal-weight.

11:51 am
undefined
PM11:52am

Halford special divis, I see

PM11:52am

BE11:56am

LFL in high margin Car Maintenance was up 8.4%, ahead of our 7.0% forecast, benefitting later in the period from colder weather after another warm December. Cycling LFL of 7.4% was also ahead of our 4% forecast and accelerated from H1’s +4.6% despite a 400bps tougher comparative. Online growth (i.e. ex-Tredz and Wheelies) was +16.3% implying a 200bps contribution to the Retail division LFL, on our estimates. Service-related LFL revenues of +13.7% added another 50bps, we think, implying core Store-only product LFL very healthy at +5.5%. Autocentre LFL decline of 0.6% was the only minor disappointment (DBe +1%, consensus +2.3%) but this division accounts for less than 10% of group EBIT and the Q4 peak lies ahead still.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

Despite strong sales, management only expects to deliver PBT in line with consensus (£74m as of last night, from Factset). Promotional activity was in line with plan, stable year-on-year, but gross margins face greater currency pressures in 2H (c200bps) than 1H (100bps). Detailed plans are now in place to mitigate the impact over time but with FX headwinds accelerating into FY18 (another 190bps) we do not expect a recovery in the next eighteen months.

BE11:57am

Following announced less than 20% stake for TyresOnTheDrive.com for up to £8m (implying EV/Sales of c.1x for this loss-making business) and the planned £20m special dividend, net debt/EBITDA is c.0.8x. This remains slightly below the 1.0x target. Capitalizing leases we estimate adjusted leverage at 3.0-3.8x depending on the multiple used (6-8x rent) albeit fixed charge cover remains over 2x. Our unchanged 310p DCF-based target uses 9.2% WACC (4.5% ERP & RFR, 1.1 beta), 6% EBIT margin (FY17e 7.0%) and 0.5% nTGR. Upside risks include: sustained stronger LFLs, better FX mitigation than anticipated.

11:58 am
PM11:58am

Dermot O’Leary of Goodbody

PM11:58am

New Irish housing supply continues to increase at a fast pace from a low level. Data
published yesterday show that there were 13,376 completions in the first 11 months of
2016, with the monthly total of 1,579 in November, the highest since December 2009. The
total for the full year is now likely to come in close to our estimate of 14,500 (+15% yoy).
Looking forward, strong trends in housing starts suggest that this trend will continue in
2017. In the eleven months to November, housing starts grew by 47% yoy. There was
stronger momentum in the second half of the year, with starts up by 73% yoy in the three
months to November. Within this, the number of units started within housing schemes more
than doubled over that three month period and grew by 49% yoy in the first 11 months.
Greater Dublin accounted for 46% of the housing starts in the 11 months, having grown by
32% yoy. However, strong growth was seen across the country, with starts in the Mid-West
up by 117% yoy and 73% yoy in the Midlands in particular.

PM11:58am

These are all exceptional growth rates, but must be seen in the context of the low
level that they are coming from. Our own housing demand forecast is c.31,000 per
annum, this compares to our completions forecast for 2017 of 18,500 (recently
revised upwards). The multi-year growth period for housing supply has a lot more
to run, aided by ongoing demand, loosening credit conditions, foreign capital and
government initiatives.
